hi.#text: All Lesbos except Methymna immediately revolts from the Athenians
who had been informed of the designs of the Mytileneans.

p.#text: : Mytilene, which was itself under oligarchical rule, had extended its authority over the three smaller places, Antissa, Pyrrha, and Eresos (c. . 5); only Methymna on the northern coast retained its democratic constitution and connexion with Athens. See W. Herbst, , 1861, and Leithuser, , 1874.

p.#text: : concerning the justice of our cause and the honesty of our intentions. , Schol.  corresponds to  above,  refers to . St. The force of the art. extends to . Khn. 451, 1; 463, 2. The whole phrase includes everything that is demanded not only by the strict letter of the law, but also by considerations of equity and morality. (On , , fair or generous dealing, see Introd. to Book I. p. 36.) The reference is, however, not merely to the present revolt of the Mytileneans from the Athenians, but to their whole mutual relation, which is to be the basis of the judgment concerning the Mytileneans for the future. They base their request for admission to the Peloponnesian alliance on grounds, first, of worthiness, showing that for the best reasons and as soon as possible they had revolted from the Athenians (c.  to c. .  2), second, of expediency and advantage to the Lacedaemonians (c. .  3-6). The two main ideas are summed up c. . 14 : Cl. and Steup understand  as subj. of , which is taken to mean,  (sich benehmen, verhalten; see on . 12). The sense would then be: Friendship between individuals and alliance between states cannot last, unless they bear themselves toward one another with a mutual recognition of honesty of purpose and are in other respects like in character. But see App. 4.

hi.#text: Intending to revolt even before the present war
we were hindered by you. Now
we have promptly taken this step not only in our own interest
but in that of the Hellenes who are enslaved by the Athenians. But as our revolt has been made too hastily and without the necessary preparations
you are the more bound to assist us
in order that your readiness to help in such cases may be known. All the circumstances are favourable. The power of the Athenians
will lose by our defection one of its strongest supports
while your fleet will receive a considerable addition.

This follows necessarily from l. 15, , which can only refer to the 250 ships of  For if 250 was the highest number reached, this, acc. to 1. 3, , must refer to the first year of the war. Besides, the reader would be more likely to reckon for himself the number of ships of the summer under consideration (428) than that of 431 B.C. : must refer grammatically to the number of ships either of 431 or 428 B.C. But as ,  (ll. 8, 14), suits neither of these cases, the author of the chapter must have meant to indicate by  this fitting out of such large armaments,a loose form of expression without parallel in Thuc. Besides, there seem to have been in the summer of 429 B.C., if one excepts the ships which may have remained on the Thracian coast after the capture of Potidaea, as well as the few at stations like Salamis and Atalante, only 40 Attie ships at sea at one time (. 21; 85. 17).

The costs of this siege had been 2000 talents (.  2). Besides, the building of ships had doubtless entailed considerable expense.

But everywhere else a Spartan king is the leader. p.#text: : supplementary explanation, by which the regular const. () is interrupted, as in c. . 8-11. Among the Colophonians who had left the upper city at the time of the Persian occupation and settled in Notium, a pro-Persian party was again developed, and this, having declared itself by a combination with Pissuthnes, was joined by the original Medizing party in Colophon (). Colophon being thus in the power of the barbarians, the pro-Athenian party had to leave Notium also, but now by treachery and violence on the part of Paches again got the upper hand. Their enemies, , had to leave Notium, which for security was made an Attic colony.11.

Alcibiades uses a similar paradox, .  7; but in neither case is the argument fair, because the question is not one of abolishing a fundamental law of the state (), but of rescinding a decree of the demos (), which could be set aside by another . Cleon's wish seems to be to confound  and  together, and to excite against the repeal of one of the former the same strong feeling which was entertained in Greece against any alteration of the latter. p.#text: :  On the omission of , see App.  is not found elsewhere, but is to be compared with such expressions as . Reiske and Cl. conjecture , considering the  simply a repetition of the preceding , and so St. writes. Kr. suggests : as the first clause contains a defiant threat, so by  the presumptive opponent is, with intentional perversion, forced into a false alternative. Whoever does not vote for the severest punishment of the Mytileneans must show () that the revolt of the Mytileneans is helpful to us, while our misfortunes are hurtful to our allies,  that they, by their revolt, which was certainly detrimental to Athens (), did us good, but themselves harm. From the impossibility of proving this is to be dedueed the necessity of extreme severity. That the guilt of revolting and the necessity of its punishment do not, however, neces sarily imply the destruction of the guilty, Cleon purposely does not say. A correct conception of the connexion shows that every change proposed is unnecessary. See Junge,  p. 9 f.

p.#text: : just as unworthy motives are imputed by Cleon to his presumptive opponent, so the hearer who would show himself favourable to the former is charged with perverse conduct throughout, and this is expressed in a series of partics. and pred. adjs., continuing to the end of the chapter. The charges made are threefold: 1) that in the deliberation more value is placed upon words than facts (); 2) that in speeches what is new and unusual is more applanded than what is tried and in the long run wholesome (); 3) that in the hankering after an ideal state actual conditions are neglected (); and finally all these errors are traced to the mania for rhetorical and sophistical performances ().16.

hi.#text: Reconsideration of the question can be only helpful. The worst enemies of safe conclusions are haste and passion
and whoever disputes the utility of speeches is either a fool
or has a personal interest in the matter. The latter is the case with those who
in order to support a bad cause
resort to slander and intimidation. Orators should renounce such means
and the state should treat with consideration not only those counsellors that usually give good advice
but even those that are not so fortunate.

hi.#text: The Mytileneans whom Paches had sent to Athens as the most guilty are put to death
the walls of the city pulled down
and the whole of Lesbos except the territory of Methymna given to Attic cleruchs
to whom the Lesbians as tenants paid a yearly rental.

:  the tenth usually consecrated to the gods. The portions of land thus assigned to the gods in ancient. Greece and Rome were considered a part of the property of the state, and like other public lands were usually let out to individuals, who were bound to keep up the sacred buildings, to provide victims and all things necessary for the sacrifices, and to maintain the priests and inferior ministers of the temples. Arn. Cf. Arist.  . 11; Xen.  4. 19, and see Boeckh,  book iii. ch. 2.9.

hi.#text: those on whom the lot fell.

p.#text: :  The lands were distributed among a definite number of citizens by lot, doubtless in such a manner that all who wished to participate in the benefit of the distribution voluntarily announced their desire, and then the lot determined who should receive a share. Boeckh,  p. 548. See also Schoemann,   ii. p. 84 f.; Grote,  vi. p. 257. Of the 2700 cleruchs thus sent out Boeckh says further (p. 554): Undoubtedly many of them returned home. But a part of them must have remained as a garrison, and probably they together with the original inhabitants composed the body politic.10.

lest we may have deceived ourselves in the expectations with which we surrendered; but we dare not even under unfavourable circumstances and hostile influences refrain from trying to defend ourselves.

hi.#text: To your unfair question as to our services rendered to you during the war
we reply that we did not break the peace
and not only in the Persian war supported the Hellenes
but also in the uprising of the Helots vigorously aided you.

p.#text: : these words are directed (see Stahl,  xcvii. p. 117 f.) against a change of  judgment on the part of the Lacedaemonians with regard to the consistent conduct of the Plataeans, which would have the saddest results for them (, as quite similarly in the transition from c.  to c. ,  is opp. to ). They are, therefore, not a justification of the Plataeans, but an admonition to the Lacedaemonians. This view necessitates Heilmann's conjecture  (agreeing with ) for . You must, however, show yourselves consistent in your judgments concerning the same course of conduct, and consider your true advantage to be only thisto have an ever-enduring sense of gratitude toward good allies for their virtue, while your own immediate interest is secured,  your true interest is subserved only where the advantage of the moment comports with lasting gratitude to deserving allies. From the first general claim () there is a transition with the aor.  to the present case, and with  definitely to the Lacedaemonians. While  is a general term for all deserving allies, the Plataeans have esp. in mind the  displayed by themselves in the Persian wars (as just described in  5), for which they claim . The matter of present advantage () is placed in the background by the emphatic position of , by the particle  (), and by : see on c. . 12.27.

p.#text: : so Steup (see  p. 31) emends the reading of the Mss.  (with friendly, not with hostile intent). His grounds are, viz.: not only does  require an obj., but it was necessary to be said here of those admitted into the city, that they were not enemies of Plataea; for it was an important point in this attempt to justify the action of the boeotizing Plataeans that at the time under consideration a state of hostilities did not exist between Thebes and Plataea. Besides, the terms used cannot be applied to the relations of citizens to their own state. Since the reference is to persons, , it is true, not , was to be expected, acc. to Thuc.'s usage; but in c. . 22 , it is generally agreed that  represents . Hude ( p. 108), who adopts Steup's conjecture, cites also Plato  221 b; Dem. xx.14.

p.#text: : these words should express the ground of the confidence of the Lacedaemonians in the justice of their question, but the traditional reading cannot be construed. The simplest remedy is, with Heilmann, Cl., St., Bm., and others, to bracket  in  The sense then is: Because they not only at all other times had, forsooth, urged the Plataeans to neutrality according to the ancient agreements with Pausanias after the Persian wars, but especially when afterwards before the circumvallation they had proposed to them to be neutral according to those agreements, since the Plataeans did not accept (the proposals), considering that by their own just demand they themselves were now  ( released from treaty obligations) and had been wronged by the Plataeans. With the view here taken of the relation of  to the preceding ( that  is an epexegetical explanation of ), any emendation of  is perhaps unnecessary. Cl. and Bm. follow St. ( 1868, p. 111) in inserting  (). Kppers ( p. 12 sq.) proposes . The simplest change would be  (. 11; 115. 6). For possible interpretations of the text as it stands, see Jow. 4.

p.#text: : more accurately, from the second of the two seafights, that at Sybota. Cf. -55. Acc. to . 6, the number of captives was 250, of whom it is said : as may be inferred from the context, not before the winter of 428-427 B.C., so that their captivity () must have lasted about five years. See App.

: gen. of price. The ransom of each man would be 3 1/5 talents, which seems enormous, even though the most of the captives were among the first men of the state (see above), and so would be, as a body of 250, a most valuable pledge in the hands of the Corinthians. Jow. thinks that the unusual amount is not a matter of much importance, as the sum was never meant to be paid. But Steup thinks that, even in a sham transaction, the demand would have to seem reasonable, in order not to excite suspicion. He cites from Philip's letter, Dem. x, a ransom of nine talents for a single man, and urges here the importance to the Corinthians of a body of 250 Corcy raean captives of such prominence, referring to the advantage which the Athenians derived from the 292 Spartans captured at Sphacteria (.  1; 117). For the ordinary ransom, see Boeckh, p. 99 f.4.

p.#text: :  as before the conflict with Corinth and other members of the Peloponnesian alliance about Epidamnus. Cf. . 10, where Corcyraean ambassadors, warning the Corinthians against going to war about Epidamnus, remark, . So that, although Corcyra had never belonged to the Peloponnesian alliance, she had had, before the contention about Epidamnus, not only peaceful, but even friendly, relations with the Peloponnesians. These were now to be renewed without affecting the treaty obligations of Corcyra to Athens. The whole decision was a kind of first triumph of the Corinthian party, since Corcyra's conflicts with Corinth and her allies about Epidamnus, and her participation in the ravaging of the Peloponnesian coasts in the summer of 425 B.C. (.  1), were disregarded, while the connexion with Athens was expressly restricted to existing conditions,  (. 8).

p.#text: :  . 11 : Leake (in Bloomfield's ed., c. . 8) thinks the Heraeum stood on the esplanade between the modern city (Corfu) and its citadel on the opposite island; and this island, not Ptychia-Vido, as others think, he considers to be the . B. Schmidt (p. 34 ff.) follows Leake with reference to the island, but locates the Heraeum near the southern shore of the bay of Kastrades, on the hill where now is the monastery of Euphemia. The Heraeum seems certainly to have been on the mainland (see on c. . 4), though Partsch (, p. 66 ff.), who decides for Vido as the , locates the temple on the modern citadel-island. See also Partsch,  1891, p. 593 ff.

:  (alliance)  c. . 7; . 8. Dem. thought that the alliance of the Aetolians with Athens would enable him, with an army composed solely of continental allies, to attack Boeotia from the west. With this view, the sent. offers no difficulty, and hence there is no occasion for bracketing, with St., , the most important words of the whole sent. 4.

: Demosthenes here first conceives the plan of attacking in the rear the most hated enemy of Athens, Boeotia. This plan is not now executed, owing to the failure of the attempt to subdue the Aetolians (c. .  2-98), but is revived in another form in the eighth year of the war ( f.), though without success (). The goal (Boeotia) being named, the proposed route, through Locris, Doris, and along the northern slopes of Parnassus, is given in detail (though not accomplished), without doubt in order that the excellence of Demosthenes's plan might be recognized.

hi.#text: The Athenians purify the island of Delos

foreign.#text: h)=n ga/r ti kai\ a)/gan qeiasmw=| te kai\ tw=| toiou/tw| proskei/menos

p.#text: :  . 3; Diod. x; Strab. p. 486, and see Curtius, , iii. p. 142. The occasion of this extraordinary homage to Apollo was doubtless the pestilence, which had reappeared in 427-26 B.C. (c. .  1-3) with undiminished force, and the object of the festival seems to have been, not to give thanks to the god for the cessation of the plague, but to bring about its cessation. So at least Diodorus, , represents the matter, and the narrative of Thuc. seems compatible with this view. For there is no reason why the beginning of the period during which the pestilence raged the second time (, c. . 4) should not be put far back into the winter of 427-26 B.C., whereas the purification of Delos must have been taken in hand early in the winter of 426-25, since acc. to c. .  7; 105.  1 the irruption of the Ambraciots into the territory of Argos (c. .  1) could have happened only shortly after the end of the preceding summer. So it was deemed proper to propitiate the wrath of the god, to which many had ascribed the pestilence ( .  4 f.), in esp. solemn wise. The oracle directing the purification may have had some connexion with Nicias's influence at that time. Cf. Thuc. . 30 . The interest manifested by Thuc. in the occurrence was prob. due not only to its historical importance, but also to the wish to correct erroneous views of his contemporaries with regard to earlier and later . Hence here, as in  ff., the digression with all its details is justifiable. See A. Baumeister,  p. 113, against G. Hermann,  i. p. 372 (=  viii. p. 388 f.).2.

p.#text: : the designation recalls indeed  an undertaking unwelcome to the Acarnanians (c. .  1 f.), but better relations had been already restored (c. .  3 f.). Further, the aor. partic. refers only to what had happened in the summer of 426 B.C. (), and does not indicate the expiration of the office of strategus. Had Demosthenes been at that time no longer strategus, he could hardly have obeyed the here mentioned invitation of the Acarnanians and hastened with 200 Messenian hoplites and sixty Athenian bowmen to the scene of action (c. . 6), and at any rate it could not have been said of him, in . 14, . kte(.: Demosthenes ( ) came from Naupactus ( c. .  3) with two hundred Messenian hoplites and sixty Athenian bowmen. As was remarked on c. . 13, he could hardly have brought these troops, if he was no longer general. From, the manner in which he is mentioned here after the twenty ships, it seems impossible that his sixty bowmen were taken from these ships. Probably there was at that time an Athenian garrison  stationed at Naupactus, so that he, even after the return (c.  98. 25) of the thirty ships of c. . 1, had control of some Athenian forces.

: understood by Bl., Cl., and Jow. as mercenaries in the pay of the Ambraciots, prob. from the neighbouring Epirot tribes, and constituting part of the 3000 hoplites of c. . 3. This view assumes that the Peloponnesians were all included in the secret agreement. The subject of  is the Peloponnesians to be supplied from the leaders of the Peloponnesians. Demosthenes negotiated with the Mantineans, Menedaius, and the leaders of the Peloponnesians, not for their personal safety only, but for the safe withdrawal of their forces; the Ambraciots, their allies, being left to their fate. (Jow.) But Steup holds that  covers all the army of Menedaius that were not Mantineans or  or . His grounds are viz.: that not all the Peloponnesians were included in the agreement is clear both from the plain meaning of l. 12 ff. and from the expressions , l. 21, and , c. . 2. Later, it is true, those entitled to withdraw are designated simply as  (c. . 10), or  (c. . 14), but again in c. . 4 they are called , and in c. . 10 the remnants of the other part of the army are spoken of as . A comparison with . 48 makes it prob. that the Mantineans also were mercenaries. The  under Eurylochus's command (c. . 7) seem, then, to have been all mercenaries, just as Brasidas led, along with 700 Helots, also 1000 Peloponnesian mercenaries to the Thracian coast (. 2; 80. 21). That the passage assumes as known that the Peloponnesian army was composed of mercenaries, though no mention is made of this fact, must be attributed, doubtless, to the lack of a final revision of his work by the author.[

kte(.: Thuc. often puts a pronominal subj., as , after a pred. subst. and before a sup. adj. which belongs to it. This posi tion of the subst. gives it a character of generality with nearly the effect of a part. gen. See on . 8. For similar concluding formulae,  . 29; 30. 19. Whether this remark of Thuc.'sin which the restrictive expressions,  and , are to be esp. noted refers to the ten years', or to the twenty-seven years' war, cannot be determined; for neither here is the number of the total loss of the Ambraciots given, nor in regard to all the great losses of the later periods of the Peloponnesian war are definite numbers for individual states known. L. Herbst ( xxxviii. p. 521 f.) cites  f. in favour of understanding  only of the ten years' war. But since Mycalessus is called in . 12 a  ( . 20 ,  ), the number of Mycalessians, including even women and children, slain by the Thracians, may very well have been less than the number of the Ambraciots that fell in the three days.22.

p.#text: :  c. . 26 . The expression , however, does not necessarily prove that the Aetolian disaster had no unpleasant consequences for Demosthenes. To it may have been due the fact that the next summer Demosthenes was  (. 14). Indeed, if one take literally the words in . 14 , and add the fact that, acc. to Arist. . 44 (p. 116 Kenyon), the election of  took place at earliest in the seventh prytany of the year, the inference seems possible that Demosthenes was not left in office even till the usual time of change of . For since the Amphilochian campaign began early in the winter ( c. .  7; 105.  1) and was of short duration, the return of Demosthenes to Athens must have occurred before mid-winter.

p.#text: : , as in c. . 10. They now obtained by treaty an unmolested departure by sea. They had already succeeded in reaching, prob. through Aetolian territory, the friendly Oeniadae (c. . 11; 94. 7; . 10), hoping to be able to embark there. This is the meaning of the passage as happily emended by G. Hermann,  (for  of the Mss.)  (, Mss.),  , as in c. . 6; 98. 18. Oberhummer, , p. 112, conjectures , but does not explain why the Ambraciots should have withdrawn, not home, but to Oeniadae. In , which he cites, the situation was quite different, for then there was no difficulty about the withdrawal of the Peloponnesians by sea, since two Peloponnesian fleets were not far from Oeniadae.

p.#text: : Bl.'s conjecture , for  of the Mss., is adopted by most recent editors. The expression  suits much better the , who lived in the interior (. 22), than the more distant . Besides, since part of the Siceliots held with the Syracusans (c. .  2), those that were allied with Athens could not properly be designated simply as . Only a part, it is true, of the Sicels were allied to Athens (c. .  1), but it was the greater part (. 61), and in . 31 these allies are called simply . In this last place, too,  is doubtless, as St. says, to be compared with  here. Furthermore, it is not likely that the Siceliot allies of Athens, of whom it is said, l. 9, , would have made this long march across the island at the risk of having their retreat cut off. In . 61, the same mistake of  for , though found in all the Mss. except three, has been corrected by all recent editors. See App.4.

p.#text: : Unger,  exli. p. 183, understands the meaning to be, that the two eruptions occurred in the same season of the year. But the  added  to  is against this explanation. Besides, it is incredible that Thuc., who acc. to what follows did not venture a definite statement even with regard to the year of the preceding eruption, should have distinctly designated the season of the year. In ,  ( . 9 ), Thuc. seems to have intended to indicate only that the eruption of 425 B.C. was not the first. This he regards as certain, whereas he does not vouch (, l. 4) for the correctness of the statement, that since the Hellenic settlement of Sicily, in all  eruptions had occurred, nor for that of his authority as to the interval between the eruption of 425 B.C. and the preceding.3.
:  c. . 12; . 3, 6; . 3; 86. 11; . 20; . 5. The reading of Laur.  is certainly a gloss.

: considered an interpolation by Cobet, v. H., and Kallenberg (, ii. p. 21). But the repetition of  in the following rel. clause should not give offence, since Thuc. is by no means careful to avoid the repetition of a word after a short interval ( , 1. 5, and  twice in l. 6). Nor can much weight be laid upon the circumstance that, allowing with Kallenberg that in . 16  the gen.  depends upon , the present passage is the only one in Thuc. in which  follows the name of a mountain likewise connected with the art. For, disregarding Hdt. . 3 , the following passages, Thuc. . 28 , . 3 , . 12 , and esp. c. . <*>   ( . 7), if considered without bias, are not so essentially different from the present passage that one must object to the latter. And, finally, the transition from the simple  to  does not seem more remarkable than  the change of expression in . 3 . At any rate, objection could more properly be raised, with Badham, against the remark , since it is not coupled with the first mention of Aetna. But this too may be due to the lack of revision on the part of the historian. 5.
: the present eruption of 425 B.C.

: refers without doubt to the eruption of Aetna mentioned in the  52, 67 ff. as contemporaneous with the battle of Plataea. But this is not sufficient reason why , which taken strictly would lead to the year 475 or 474 instead of 479 B.C. should either be considered as a  (see Boeckh in  ii. p. 339), or changed, acc. to Kr.'s conjecture, into  (or  ) . For unquestionably Thuc. indicates by  that he does not vouch for the correctness of the number given by him. The expression  is also decidedly against the assumption of Bdinger,  i. p. 39, that Thuc. chose the date  with reference to the first Pythian ode of Pindar (474 B.C.), in which,  ff., an eruption of Aetna is deseribed. At most, Thuc.'s  may have fixed the date by inference from Pindar's ode.6.

kte(.: from his manner of expression it is clear that Thuc. can have had no knowledge, when he wrote this passage, of an eruption of Aetna later than that of 425 B.C. Otherwise he must have expressed himself definitely as to three eruptions, and not with , since acc. to l. 2 two eruptions are regarded by him as facts. Evidently, then, Thuc.'s authority must have mentioned, in addition to the  of l. 5, a still earlier eruption. See Ullrich,  p. 92 f., and Introd. to Book 1. p. 18, N. 38. Another eruption is said by Diod. x and Orosius  to have occurred in the year 396. Thuc., therefore, must have either died before 396, or never revised this passage.
